Alvin Thomas, Ph.D.</font></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif">For over 30 years forensic psychology has been established as a distinct specialty within the field of psychology. Though applying psychological research to the legal system goes back as far as 1885, it was officially recognized by the American Psychological Association in 2001 and has since experienced rapid growth.&nbsp; As the field of forensic psychology continues to advance, it is imperative training and educational curricula adequately prepares future practitioners and researchers alike.</font></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif">To read this column, please click <a href="https://ap-ls.wildapricot.org/resources/EmailTemplates/2019_06%20June%20AP-LS%20Newsletter/ExpertOpinion6_19.pdf" target="_blank">here</a>.</font></p><font><font><strong></strong></font></font><p style="margin: 0px 0px 10.66px; Perlin, Esq. &amp; Heather Ellis Cucolo</font></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif">The two of us have taught together, written together, consulted and presented together for years. Mostly, we have done this with lawyers, law students, psychologists and psychology students. For 14 years, one of us (MLP) ran an online mental disability law program at New York Law School (NYLS), and for the last five, HEC has run it. Through this program, we have offered courses at NYLS and at other law schools and graduate schools (including a school of professional psychology) throughout the US and in multiple foreign nations. We also, for eight years, ran a masters’ program in mental disability law studies, and psychologists regularly made up a majority of students in that program. And we created a joint program with John Jay so that students could receive a J.D. from NYLS and an M.A. in forensic psychology from Jay.</font></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><font face="Trebuchet
